name: Boeing 747
summary: The Boeing 747, known as the 'Queen of the Skies', revolutionized long-haul air travel when introduced in 1970.
details:
Capacity: Up to 660 passengers (in high-density configurations)

Range: ~8,000 nautical miles

Engines: 4 turbofan engines

Fun Fact: The 747 was the first wide-body aircraft in history.

name: Airbus A380
summary: The Airbus A380 is the largest passenger airliner in the world, designed for long-haul international routes.
details:
Capacity: Over 850 passengers (all economy)

Range: 8,000 nautical miles

Engines: 4 Rolls-Royce Trent 900 or Engine Alliance GP7200

Fun Fact: First commercial flight was operated by Singapore Airlines.

name: Lockheed C-130 Hercules
summary: A military workhorse, the C-130 Hercules is a tactical airlifter used worldwide for troop and cargo transport.
details:
Capacity: 92 passengers or 64 airborne troops

Range: 2,000+ nautical miles

Engines: 4 turboprops

Fun Fact: In service for over 65 years across 60+ countries.

name: Concorde
summary: The Concorde was a turbojet-powered supersonic passenger airliner that flew faster than the speed of sound.
details:
Capacity: About 100 passengers

Speed: Mach 2.04 (over 1,350 mph)

Range: ~3,900 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Cut the New York to London trip to ~3.5 hours.

name: Airbus Beluga
summary: Named for its resemblance to the whale, the Beluga transports oversized aircraft parts across Europe.
details:
Payload: 47 tons

Volume: 1,400 m³ cargo hold

Fun Fact: Used to transport full A350 wings and fuselage sections.

name: Airbus A300
summary: The Airbus A300 was the world's first twin-engine wide-body airliner.
details:
Capacity: ~266 passengers

Range: ~4,000 nautical miles

Fun Fact: First Airbus aircraft ever built, launched the Airbus brand in 1972.

name: Airbus A310
summary: The Airbus A310 was a shorter, more efficient variant of the A300.
details:
Capacity: ~280 passengers

Range: ~5,000 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Used as a multi-role tanker and cargo aircraft by several air forces.

name: Airbus A320
summary: The A320 is one of the best-selling commercial jets globally, known for its fly-by-wire technology.
details:
Capacity: 140–240 passengers (A318 to A321 variants)

Range: ~3,300 nautical miles

Fun Fact: First commercial aircraft with full fly-by-wire controls.

name: Airbus A321
summary: A stretched variant of the A320, ideal for short to medium-haul routes.
details:
Capacity: ~185 to 240 passengers

Range: ~4,000 nautical miles (with A321XLR)

Fun Fact: Popular in transatlantic low-cost service.

name: Airbus A330
summary: A wide-body twinjet used for medium to long-haul routes.
details:
Capacity: ~250–440 passengers

Range: ~7,200 nautical miles

Fun Fact: One of Airbus’s most versatile aircraft in both cargo and passenger versions.

name: Airbus A340
summary: A four-engine long-haul airliner ideal for ultra-long range flights.
details:
Capacity: ~250–375 passengers

Range: ~7,900 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Known for its quiet cabin and non-stop intercontinental service.

name: Airbus A350
summary: The A350 is a modern long-haul aircraft made from carbon-fiber-reinforced composites.
details:
Capacity: ~300–410 passengers

Range: ~9,700 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Competes directly with Boeing’s 787 and 777.

name: Boeing 707
summary: The Boeing 707 launched the jet age in commercial aviation.
details:
Capacity: ~150 passengers

Range: ~5,000 nautical miles

Fun Fact: First successful commercial jetliner by Boeing.

name: Boeing 717
summary: A small, efficient regional jet originally developed as the MD-95.
details:
Capacity: ~110 passengers

Range: ~2,060 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Last commercial airliner produced at Long Beach.

name: Boeing 727
summary: A trijet designed for smaller airports and shorter runways.
details:
Capacity: ~149 passengers

Range: ~2,700 nautical miles

Fun Fact: First commercial airplane to reach 1,000 sales.

name: Boeing 737
summary: The most produced commercial aircraft in aviation history.
details:
Capacity: 85–230 passengers (varies by variant)

Range: ~3,000–3,850 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Over 11,000 built and counting.

name: Boeing 757
summary: A narrow-body airliner with long-range capability and excellent performance.
details:
Capacity: ~200 passengers

Range: ~3,900 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Used extensively for transatlantic flights.

name: Boeing 767
summary: A wide-body aircraft used for both passenger and cargo operations.
details:
Capacity: ~200–375 passengers

Range: ~5,990 nautical miles

Fun Fact: Still used today by UPS, FedEx, and many airlines.

name: Boeing 777
summary: A long-range wide-body twinjet known for its efficiency and capacity.
details:
Capacity: ~314–396 passengers

Range: ~8,555 nautical miles

Fun Fact: First commercial aircraft fully designed with CAD (computer-aided design).

name: Boeing 787 Dreamliner
summary: A fuel-efficient, long-range aircraft with composite materials and improved cabin comfort.
details:
Capacity: ~242–330 passengers

Range: ~7,355–7,635 nautical miles

Fun Fact: First airliner with an all-composite fuselage.
